awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: Analysis, Identification and Mitigation of Delay Performance Bottlenecks of Network Infrastructure in Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern societies are witnessing the prevalence of a wide assortment of distributed cyber-physical systems (CPS) built upon network infrastructure. International standards for mission-critical CPS applications, such as industrial process control systems and avionics, require their network infrastructure to provide deterministic delay performance. However, the problem of integrating CPS theoretical concepts with real-world network performance remains largely unexplored. This project addresses this open problem so that feedback control CPS in network-challenged spaces can be analyzed formally. The project result can be applied to many other CPS application domains involving real-time control and adaptation, such as vehicular control and communication systems, industrial process control, and network-on-chip systems. Broader impacts include developing publicly-available open-source software for the research community and educating a wide spectrum of audience, from high-school and undergraduate students to academic and industry researchers, by offering seminars and tutorials and organizing a workshop with strategies to maximize the participation of under-represented groups.

The main goal of this project is to establish a systematic approach to the design, characterization, and refinement of network infrastructure in CPS as a breakthrough result for designing and implementing CPS with time-critical tasks. Different from existing studies relying on predefined or presumed device/system specifications, the new approach balances theoretical analyses with empirical evaluations by exploring network-calculus-based modeling of networking devices and traffic sources from measurements. This project also focuses on non-feedforward networks, in contrast to state-of-the-art methods targeting feedforward networks, and includes investigation of compositional, algebraic, and optimization-based approaches to delay performance analysis of non-feedforward networks and research on identification and mitigation of delay performance bottlenecks in networked CPS. This project will use PLC (Programmable Logic Controller)-based industrial automation systems for case studies, not only demonstrating the usage and capabilities of the systematic approach but also providing reference implementation of related algorithms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Modern societies are witnessing the prevalence of a wide assortment of distributed cyber-physical systems (CPS) built upon network infrastructure. International standards for mission-critical CPS applications, such as industrial process control systems and avionics, require their network infrastructure to provide deterministic delay performance. However, the problem of integrating CPS theoretical concepts with real-world network performance remains largely unexplored. This project, CPS: Breakthrough: Analysis, Identification and Mitigation of Delay Performance Bottlenecks of Network Infrastructure in Cyber-Physical Systems (NSF Awards # 1646458 and # 2146968), addresses this open problem so that feedback control CPS in network-challenged spaces can be analyzed formally.

Our research outcomes span from analysis to identification and to mitigation of delay performance bottlenecks of network infrastructure in CPS. The results have been published in 13 journal and conference papers and presented at top-tier and flagship conferences. We have expanded the capability of network calculus for delay performance analysis and the functionality of time-sensitive networking (TSN) for identification and mitigation of delay performance bottlenecks. The applications of CPS studied in this project include industrial control systems with programmable logic controllers, avionic systems, and drone-as-a-service systems. Two PhD dissertations and two Master’s degree theses have been built upon the research of this project.

The research outcomes establish a systematic approach using network calculus and time-sensitive networking to the design, characterization, and refinement of network infrastructure in CPS for time-critical tasks. For example, we show that the problem of worst-case delay bounding for a wireless parallel redundancy protocol network can be solved by performing network-calculus-based analysis and closed-form expressions of worst-case delays can be derived, which has not been found previously and allows industrial control system architects/designers to compute worst-case delay bounds for tasks in their respective application domains of interest. A recent outcome is a method addressing limitations of existing approaches when applying network calculus for analyzing delay performance bottlenecks of non-feedforward networks in CPS, which adds a new tool to the existing toolbox of delay performance analysis.

Another research outcome is TSN-Peeper, an efficient traffic monitor in TSN, which addresses a previously unsolved issue of identifying delay performance bottlenecks of TSN for CPS. We have also designed TSN-Violation Mitigation (TSN-VM), which periodically reconfigures the schedule at each TSN switch in a distributed way, to mitigate the delay performance bottlenecks. The outcomes of our original research have potential to impact the future evolution of TSN and network infrastructure of CPS for time-critical applications.

Broader impacts of project outcomes also include educating a wide spectrum of audience, from high-school and undergraduate students to academic and industry researchers, through our publications and publicly-available open-source software and by tutorial, seminar, and outreach activities. The project has a website (https://liangcheng.info/projects/cps-breakthrough/) disseminating the project results, software, and documentation. For example, one of our papers, the first paper that surveys available network calculus tools, focuses on describing and comparing twelve network calculus tools for analyzing network infrastructure in real-time CPS. The project website provides software links, implementation code, and documentation for researchers to use these tools and study the results described in the paper, such as functionalities, advantages, and disadvantages of the tools. The project has also reached academic and industry researchers through a tutorial at a top-tier conference and invited talks at higher education institutions.

The project has also provided research and education opportunities to 2 PhD students, 5 Master’s degree students, 7 undergraduate students, and K-12 students. A strategy we have used to maximize the participation of under-represented groups is working with local schools and organizations in the City of Toledo and the Toledo metropolitan area. For example, we presented our research to about 100 students at the Aerospace and Natural Science Academy of Toledo in October 2022 and to close to 40 students from Toledo, Ohio and Tango, Tanzania for Drone Academy in November 2022. We also organized drone club activities for middle- and high-school students at the research lab of this project in Spring 2023. More information and activity photos are available at the project website (https://liangcheng.info/projects/cps-breakthrough/).
